Kidney Int Suppls. 2013; 3: 1-150. Screening Tools: estimated glomerular filtration rate Considered the best overall index of Kidney function. Normal glomerular filtration rate varies according to age, sex, and body size, and declines with age. The National Kidney Foundation recommends using the chronic kidney disease-EPI Creatinine Equation (2009) to estimate glomerular filtration rate. Other useful calculators related to Kidney disease include MDRD and Cockroft Gault. Appears to be substantial variation among individuals possibly related to initial nephron mass/number and other factors Reasons for decline are not fully understood Age-related decline in glomerular filtration rate was formerly considered part of normal aging Decreased glomerular filtration rate in the elderly is an independent predictor o of adverse outcomes, such as death and cardiovascular disease. Decreased glomerular filtration rate in the elderly requires adjustment in drug o dosages, as with other patients with chronic kidney disease. Coresh J, et al. Am J Kidney Dis. 2003; 41(1): 1-12. Other Changes in the Kidney with Aging Decrease in renal mass (mostly from cortex) Impaired Sodium and Potassium excretion and conservation Decreased concentrating and diluting capability Impaired excretion of acid loads Increased dependence on renal prostaglandins to maintain intrarenal perfusion (ie NSAIDs effect aging kidneys more) Increased susceptibility to contrast dye and ischemia Impaired recovery after insults Taffet GE. Screening Tools: albumin-creatinine ratio Urinary albumin-to-Creatinine ratio (albumin-creatinine ratio) is calculated by dividing albumin concentration in milligrams by Creatinine concentration in grams. Creatinine assists in adjusting albumin levels for varying Urine o concentrations, which allows for more accurate results versus albumin alone. Spot Urine albumin-to-Creatinine ratio for quantification of proteinuria New guidelines classify albuminuria as mild, moderately or o severely increased First morning void preferable 24hr Urine test rarely necessary Assign Albuminuria Category Albuminuria Categories in chronic kidney disease Category albumin-creatinine ratio (magnesium/g) Terms A1 30 Normal to mildly increased A2 30-300 Moderately increased A3 300 Severely increased Relative to young adult level. albumin-creatinine ratio 30-300 magnesium/g for 3 months indicates chronic kidney disease. Classification of chronic kidney disease This newer classification scheme puts more emphasis on proteinuria In practice, this is a significant factor in diagnosis and management of chronic kidney disease A Low glomerular filtration rate with no proteinuria and slow progression probably o requires less monitoring and could be followed by Primary Care A relatively High glomerular filtration rate with heavy proteinuria is more o concerning and should be referred more aggressively Also provides a helpful recommendation for how often to monitor patients Clinical Evaluation of chronic kidney disease Clinical Evaluation of Patients with chronic kidney disease Blood Hypertension hemoglobin hemoglobin A1c Serum Creatinine Use a glomerular filtration rate estimating equation or clearance measurement; dont rely on o serum Creatinine concentration alone Be attentive to changes in Creatinine over time--even in normal range o Urinalysis Urine sediment o Albuminuria/Proteinuria Spot Urine for Protein/Creatinine or albumin/Creatinine ratio o Electrolytes, Blood glucose, CBC Clinical Evaluation of Patients with chronic kidney disease Depending on stage: albumin, phosphate, calcium, vitamin D, intact parathyroid hormone Renal imaging Depending on age and PMHx Light chain assay, serum or Urine Protein o electrophoresis (SPEP, UPEP) HIV, HCV, HBV tests o Complements, other serologies o limited role unless specific reason (e. g. systemic symptoms, hematuria) Indications for Nephrology Referral Acute Kidney injury or abrupt sustained fall in glomerular filtration rate 2 glomerular filtration rate 30 milliliters per minute/1. 73m (glomerular filtration rate categories G4-G5) Persistent albuminuria (albumin-creatinine ratio 300 magnesium/g) Atypical Progression of chronic kidney disease Urinary red cell casts, red blood cell more than 20 per HPF sustained and not readily explained Hypertension refractory to treatment with 4 or more antihypertensive agents Persistent abnormalities of serum Potassium Anemia thought to be related to chronic kidney disease Recurrent or extensive nephrolithiasis Hereditary Kidney disease Progression of chronic kidney disease is defined as one or more of the following: 1) A decline in glomerular filtration rate category accompanied by a 25% or greater drop in estimated glomerular filtration rate from baseline; and/or 2) rapid progression of chronic kidney disease defined as a sustained decline in estimated glomerular filtration rate of more than 5ml/min/1. 73m2/year. Observational Studies of Early vs. Late Nephrology Consultation However there are no randomized trials of early versus late nephrology referral in the literature. Interpreting the approximately 50 published o observational studies that assessed the timing of nephrology referral is complicated by heterogeneity in study design and variable definitions of early referral. Greater choice of treatment options, including home hemodialysis, peritoneal Dialysis and preemptive Kidney transplantation, are associated with early initiation of nephrology services Case Question 3 All of the following adult patients should be referred for nephrology consultation, EXCEPT? Questions and Self-Assessment Take Home Points PCPs play an important role Identify risk factors Know patients estimated glomerular filtration rate and albuminuria to help guide appropriate treatment strategies Partner and refer to specialist Self Assessment Questions 1. Modifiable risk factors for chronic kidney disease include: o Di abetes o Hypertension o History of acute kidney injury o Frequent nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug use All of the above o Rationale: Diabetes, hypertension, history of acute kidney injury, and frequent nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug use can all damage the kidneys and are risk factors for chronic kidney disease 2. National Kidney Foundation recommends the following calculator be used to estimate glomerular filtration rate for chronic kidney disease staging: chronic kidney disease-EPI o o MDRD o Cockroft-Gault o All of the above Rationale: chronic kidney disease-EPI is less biased than MDRD particularly at High GFRs and performs equally, or better compared to the MDRD equation in various age groups and all body mass index groups (except those with a body mass index 20) and is calibrated for the IDMS standardized Creatinine available from all labs Questions and Answers Additional Resources Centers for Disease Control and Preventions chronic kidney disease Surveillance Project: kidney disease National Kidney Disease Education Program (NKDEP): National Kidney Foundation chronic kidney disease: A Global Public Health Crisis National Kidney Foundation App: GLOMERULAR estimated glomerular filtration rate (glomerular filtration rate) Calculator Disease Outcomes Quality Initiative/glomerular filtration rate Kidney Disease Improving Global Outcomes (Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes) 2012 chronic kidney disease Guidelines Disease: Improving Global Outcomes. org/home/ The National Kidney Foundation Kidney Disease Outcomes Quality Initiative (National Kidney Foundation Kidney Disease Outcomes Quality Initiative) National Kidney Foundation Safety card for Patient Care: The chart summarizes cautionary safety recommendations for physicians when prescribing medications in people with chronic kidney disease.
